Pablo looked distressed. He grabbed the litre-bottle of Brahma beer and, pouring, moaned aloud: "I can't believe it. The Lençóis have been taken off the seven wonders shortlist – all because the local government wouldn't pay the 320 reales [$199] registration fee."

Pablo was my guide around São Luis, a colonial city on Brazil's north-eastern coast still relatively unfamiliar to European tourists. I had no idea what he was talking about. I'd also come here to see this natural wonder – the Parque Nacional dos Lençóis Maranhenses, a surreal and beautiful coastal desert of sweeping dunes where rainwater collects to create freshwater lagoons. They are just three hours south of São Luis and while the city is a draw in itself, the dunes are deservedly the region's top attraction.

"You see, they're voting for seven new world wonders, and the Lençóis national park was on the website. But the government, which spends millions of reales on parties and local events, wouldn't pay the registration fee. It looks as if Rio de Janeiro's Sugar Loaf Mountain will be entered instead."

Pablo was referring not to the Unesco World Heritage scheme, but to a global election campaign to find seven new natural wonders of the world organised by a Swiss foundation-cum-enterprise. On the page relating to the Lençóis, the website advises: "This nominee is not yet officially supported" and it adds in capital letters: "Without an official supporting committee (OSC), a nominee cannot participate in the next stages of the New 7 Wonders of Nature campaign."

I contacted the organisation to find out if the local supporters of Lençois had lost out simply because they hadn't paid a registration fee. Stephanie McNamara, the organisations "communications consultant" wrote back almost immediately to tell me I should support UK sites, enthusing "There is no registration fee - just go ahead - vote and create an OSC."

The next day I put the question to McNamara again, wondering how Pablo had got it so wrong. She explained: "We introduced the nominal registration fee to make sure that the OSC for each nominee were serious and committed, and it also helps us defray the administrative costs. As a non-profit organisation which has never received any public funding or taxpayer's monies whatsoever, we must not only be as fiscally careful as we can, but must also ask the actual beneficiaries of the campaign to contribute at least a bit to the administrative costs."

So someone or something does have to pay the sum - nominal in Europe, not so nominal in the developing world, which probably explains why many rivers, hills, beaches and waterfalls getting plenty of votes in Mongolia, Nepal, Eritrea and elsewhere remain officially unsupported.

And that set me to wondering about wonders. Last year there was a vote for seven man-made wonders of the world, in which the likes of Mexico's Chitzen-Itzá, China's Great Wall and Brazil's Christ the Redeemer (Rio again) beat the Moais of Easter Island and the Statue of Liberty. Announced on July 7 2007, the "new seven wonders" were supposedly decided after 100 million votes were cast online. The final seven had all the authority of those lists of memorable movie scenes, all-time great pop records and unforgettable comedy moments that are churned out on British television.

The people behind both sets of seven wonders call themselves the Seven Wonders Foundation. The foundation was set up by Bernard Weber, a Swiss-born Canadian, who, the website informs us, "has had a varied career as a filmmaker, museum curator, aviator, and explorer". While the organisation claims its main purpose is to protect buildings and the environment, Weber – in his 7 answers to 7 questions – says, "So far, we have made enough money to cover our main costs, which is very positive since many good ideas often fall apart because of insufficient funding. And it is our intention to continue to grow our revenues in the future, for example through sponsor and licensing partnerships, and indeed to make much more so that we can generate a surplus to support the important objectives of the New7Wonders Foundation."

At which point, one has to ask if Pharaoh Khufu had to register the pyramids to get them into the original list of seven wonders? Did the gardener who liked to hang his creative genius around Babylon pay 199 gold coins to get the recognition he deserved?

Some Brazilian news media, such as the local news website Zill, are saying that the Lençóis were left out because of a bureaucratic loophole. But if Pablo is right, and the local government didn't fancy paying to be part of some completely random, ultimately commercial ranking, then I entirely sympathise. When I checked the website, I found that 10 of the top 25 entries on the shortlist still have no official committee to back them. The UK had no sites being sponsored at all. One is left to assume that either apathy rules or countries are too proud to enter a raffle for greatness.

When I went to the Lençóis, there were roughly 50 people wandering around the edge of this 270-sq-km park. There was plenty of space and I was able to go for a swim in my very own private lagoon – cool water, cloudless skies, not even the sound of anyone else splashing. This, I reflected, is what wonder is about – and experiences, whether on our travels or at home, should be measured according to personal delight, and not because that sector of society that has access to the internet, likes to vote and believes lists really matter, condescends to determine what is and isn't wonderful.

The new seven wonders of nature will be announced in 2010.

One of the great things about traveling is that you pick up on things that the guidebooks and the seasoned experts never tell you about. I've just spent three weeks touring northern California and, along with my family, we were all struck by one wonderful fact. Cleanliness. There was no litter. Not in the public transport system, Bart, serving the San Francisco Bay area, nor in the national parks of Yosemite, Lake Tahoe, the Redwoods of Muir Forest, nor the pristine Tomales Bay of Marin county. Even though a baseball game at the San Francisco Giants stadium turned into a huge fast food munch-in, the debris was minimal.

At Lake Merritt, in gritty Oakland, where we passed some hours at its sweet children's theme park, Fairyland, the lunch-time trash was carefully deposited, parents carefully collecting children's Coke cans. Now I arrive home to find that American-born Bill Bryson is lecturing Britain about being a nation of disgusting fly-tipping litterbugs. How right he is.

But I think there are profound cultural differences. First, fines and enforcement. I was so struck by the complete lack of litter, that I asked a recently retired state trooper from Pleasanton, in the Bay area, why this should be. He said that the prominently displayed warnings, of a $1,000 fine for litter across the state, was one reason - he had handed out plenty of fines in his time. Yet there were no litter warnings or state troopers around on the shores of Lake Tahoe, a Sierra Nevada gem, which were infested, daily, with families obsessively conducting barbeques. In Yosemite, more than two million people visit its valley areas, lakes, waterfalls and viewing points, which were all clean as a whistle. In part, perhaps, this urge to clear up in national parks is driven by personal safety; a fear of wild bears (we saw four). Everywhere there are warnings to place litter (as well as food) in bear-proof receptacles.

But there is also, I suspect, a deeply inbred respect, within the American psyche, for its fantastic natural environment. A shared pride in some of the most pristine and magnificent countryside in the world. To this Briton's eye, I'd also note that this wilderness is accessible - a week's family car pass to Yosemite is just $20, and camping is cheap to free.

The park also operates a free junior ranger programme for children, every morning, on a different topic natural environment, plus evening campfires. A family can hire a fully equipped campsite (tent, table, chairs etc) for $20 a night. American parents of modest means said they were returning, after coming as children to camp with their parents. This is something the National Trust might study, to our national benefit. For sure, Americans eat far too much, they're in the grip of an obesity crisis, are totally dependent on cars, and are embarrassingly prone to flying the stars and stripes at their gates and drives. But they certainly have far more respect for their open and public spaces than we do here.

That's why it takes a more sensitive American eye to point out a horrible home truth - our mounting squalor. The only thing I would say in our defence is that I usually spend August not in California, but in southern Italy, well south of Naples. Believe me, the Italians I encounter are even more messy in their public places - especially the beaches - than Britons, though I've never really worked out why that should be.

WWF UK has launched an ad campaign attacking Shell's environmental claims after winning a battle to get a press ad by the fuel giant banned as "greenwash".

WWF's ad campaign will launch on giant digital screens at Waterloo station in London today trumpeting its victory by stating that "Shell can't hide the environmental impact of their oil sand projects".

The 20-second WWF ad accuses Shell of "greenwash" over a press ad in the Financial Times earlier this year suggesting the company's Canadian oil sand extraction operation was sustainable.

In the Waterloo ad, WWF, which interspersed the copy with images of stripped mining landscape in Canada, claims that the Shell operation releases three times more greenhouse gases than conventional oil production. The Waterloo ad was created by the agency Kitcatt Nohr Alexander Shaw.

WWF lodged a complaint with the Advertising Standards Authority about a national press ad that Shell launched in the FT in February.

The ad opens with the headline "We invest today's profits in tomorrow's solutions".

In the ad, Shell talks of the need to invest in technology to "continue to secure a profitable and sustainable future".

Shell also said that in the race to find more energy to fuel global demand there was a need to "find new ways of managing carbon emissions to limit climate change".

The FT ad gave examples included Shell building the biggest refinery in the US, "exploring a new generation of bio fuels", and unlocking "the potential of the vast Canadian oil sands deposit".

WWF complained to the ASA that Shell's Canadian oil sand operation and building the biggest US refinery - actually an expanded redevelopment of an existing facility at Port Arthur in Texas - does not help provide a sustainable future or sustainable energy production.

Shell argued that to meet vast energy requirements it had to look beyond conventional sources of oil and gas, "but also the development of vast resources of unconventional oil and gas, such as oil sands".

The ASA said that the use of the word "sustainable" throughout the ad was defined as "primarily in environmental terms".

Because Shell had not provided evidence that it was "effectively" managing carbon emissions from its oil sands projects "in order to limit climate change", the ASA deemed that the ad was misleading.

The ASA came to the same conclusion about Shell's claims about the redevelopment of the Port Arthur oil refinery and said it should not be shown again in its current form.

You can stop worrying about the women's 470, though, after Christina Bassadone and Saskia Clark finished 15th and 13th in to finish the day in 11th. Do likewise for men's 49er team Stevie Morrison and Ben Rhodes, who are now eighth - in good part because they were disqualified for a false start in race seven. Paul Goodison, meanwhile, was fourth in Athens but sits seventh here after finishing 15th in his third race.

10.30am: "I saw Eddie the Eagle Edwards doing a personal appearance at the Big Chill festival last week and I'm sure he was wearing a piece of tinsel wound his neck," honks Chris Riley. "That makes him the most decorated Olympian I have ever seen!" I'm going to give the benefit of the doubt here and assume Chris has been up all night watching Olympic rounders.

10.35am: USA v Nigeria is still 0-0 despite some enthusiastic trumpet and drum playing in the stands. If I were you, I'd take this moment to check out our gallery of the funniest pictures of the day from Beijing.

10.44am: rowing Great Britain's women's eight are off to a bad start in the repechage at Shunyi. They need to finish in the top four to make the final ...

10.46am: rowing... which they do comfortably enough in the end, finishing third behind Canada and Holland. Australia also make it through, but Germany, whose rowers have been having a stinker across the board here so far, are out after coming in fifth.

10.55am: France have their tenth medal - and their first gold - after Steeve Guenot beat Kyrgyzstan's Kanatbek Begaliev in the men's 66kg Greco-Roman wrestling. Fiona Pennie is up shortly in the women's K1 kayaking heats and needs either some serious improvement, some help from her opponents or both to make the semi-finals after finishing 19th in the first heat. She needs to make the top 15 to go through.

11.02am: Now I'm no kayaking expert, but I'm fairly confident that flipping upside down (yes, yes - "capsizing") is not good, and that's what just happened to Aleksandra Perova. I'm fairly sure that's good news for Pennie, who's up right now.

11.04am: A much better run from Pennie, but she still picked up four seconds in penalties, so it's going to be tight. I'll keep you posted when everyone else has finished, but in the meantime I can tell you that Team GB's three blondes of sailing - Sarah Ayton, Sarah Webb and Pippa Wilson have finished second in race seven of the Yngling and remain top of the standing, as does Ben Ainslie in the Finn after a second-place finish of his own. The rest of today's sailing has been postponed due to low visibility.

11.09am: It's not looking good for Pennie - she's 15th with two others still to go.

11.12am: Yup, Pennie's out, which is rather disappointing for the woman who was the fifth-highest ranked of any of the entrants into this year's competition. Still, it's not all bad - in a matter of minutes you'll be treated to some superlative web-based text commentary from Howard Swains, who will be taking over this gig as soon as he's done doing whatever it is that he's currently doing.

11.15am: Looks like whatever it is that Howard is doing will take a while longer, so here's an email from a man known only as "Dave". "If only the soft/hand/volleyball was as entertaining as your updates," he flatters. "The Olympic TV coverage (as mentioned at 10am) in SA would have us believe that this is the school-yard world championships. Let the next Olympics get back to reality, chuck the tennis, baseball, football & hockey - we get enough of those already - and just make it 8 days of track & field, swimming, gymnastics and table tennis. OK, and trampoline."

11.22am: Those, who - unlike Dave - are feeling starved of football in right now could do a lot worse than perusing Rob Smyth's excellent Premier League preview piece on Stoke City. Soccerball fans may be more excited/upset to hear that USA are 1-0 down to Nigeria. Holland are currently drawing 0-0 with Japan in the other match in that group, so as it stands both USA and Nigeria go through, but if Holland scored now then USA would be going out.

11.30am Right, Howard's here, and I"m off. Cheers for all your emails - keep sending them on to Howard at hswains@gmail.com

11.37am: Hello folks, this is the first time I've ever been the fourth man in a four-man byline.

11.40am: Sam Morgan from Cardiff gets a mention simply because he's the first into my inbox. "Where and when will GB win their next medal????" he asks, the four question marks surprisingly threatening. Well, I don't know when Sam, but I'm confidently predicting Beijing for the where.

11.45am: The television coverage has now moved away from re-runs of the Georgian beach-volleyball victory and into the swimming pool, where they're...swimming. Fran Halsall, of Team GB!, leads after 50m in the 100m freestyle, and she's still there at the end. A heat victory for the Brit, in a time that is described as "good".

11.50am: Kevin Mackenzie, who is one letter away from being the former Sun editor, gotchas: "Dave's use of the word trampoline (11:15am) has had the effect of my not being able to think about anything but the episode of The Simpsons where Homer buys one but calls it a 'tramamampoline'. Which, now I see them both written down, looks no less ridiculous." Funny, because as I read that, I was looking at Sharon Davies on the television, who is kind of Simpson-esque under the peculiar yellow lights in the swimming pool on the telly.

11.53am: The first heats of the women's 100m freestyle are over and Britain's Fran Halsall cruised into the semi-finals fifth fastest. Her sub-54 seconds time is excellent, apparently.

11.59am: As ever at the Games, there are about 30 events going on at any one time which, thanks to the internet, we can know about but struggle to follow with only one pair of eyes. Still, at half-time in the football, Cameroon and Italy are 0-0; Korea lead Honduras 1-0; and Holland lead Japan 1-0. Later on, we've got Ivory Coast v Australia; Argentina v Serbia (remember that match in the World Cup?); China v Brazil; New Zealand v Belgium.

12.02pm: Roger Federer is playing in the tennis at the moment, if anyone is interested in the World No2-elect. The Swiss is a set up but 3-0 down in the second to Tomas Berdych.

12.08pm The men's 200m backstroke heats are underway in the pool, with British hopes lying with Gregor Tait. Meanwhile, Amnat Ruenroeng has just pummeled Jack Willie, from Papua New Guinea, in the boxing, prompting the line: "Poor little Jack Wille" from the internet commentator. And repeated here, of course.

12.16pm Gregor Tait finishes second in his heat to Ryan Lochte of the United States, but it's good enough to take him into the semi-finals. Meanwhile, our bloggers have been getting their copy in early, so catch up on Richard Williams on Emma Pooley; Sean Ingle on women's gymnastics and Lawrence Donegan on the sand storm between Georgia and Russia.

12.20pm Johan van Slooten of the Netherlands has a fact and a question: "Dutch judo legend," (takes his word for it) "and gold medal winner in Tokyo 1964 Anton Geesink lives in the city of Utrecht, in ... Anton Geesink Street! The street was so named after his win in 1964, and years later Anton actually moved into this street. Is he the only athlete ever to live in his own street?" That's one for The Knowledge, Olympic edition.*
*Does not exist.

12.27pm: Roger Federer is 5-4 down in the second set, but serving. The football matches are now over, I believe, although the official site is struggling to keep up. Holland beat Japan, Nigeria beat USA 2-1 (freeing up Brad Guzan to join up with Villa, I think, since the Americans appear to be out), Korea beat Honduras, and Cameroon drew 0-0 with Pierluigi Casiraghi's Italy.

12.36pm: Kirsty Balfour is up in the 200m breaststroke. No one seems to be expecting much from her, so I'm going to root for the underdog. Roger Federer, meanwhile, is now serving to stay in the second set, ... and succeeds, taking the match to a tiebreak. Balfour, meanwhile, is outside of the top three at 100m.

12.39pm: Kirsty Balfour is all but out of the 200m, finishing sixth in her heat. Rebecca Sohn broke the Olympic record, so Balfour had it tough, especially from lane one. She's not officially done, but she's in tears during the post-race interview and "feels like she's let everyone down" according to Sharon Davies.

12.44pm: Roger Federer is through to the quarter-finals. He wins the second-set tie-break against Berdych and goes through 6-3, 7-6. Serena Williams is up next, with Jamie and Andy Murray playing in the doubles on an outer court. There's not going to be any telly coverage of that one, apparently, so we'll only be able to bring you the score updates, rather than some more glittering prose.

12.52pm: The Olympic football match between China and Brazil is underway, and Brazil have started with Ronaldinho, Lucas and Diego. Manchester United's Dong is playing for China.

12.59pm: Flicking through all these Olympic channels, there's not much chance to follow any event for longer than about five minutes. I'd quite like to watch a bit of that football match, even if Brazil are through to the next round, but there's the men's individual medley heats starting now too. A Ukrainian and a Russian light flyweight are also duffing one another up on another channel, with the Russian on top at the moment.

1.03pm Britain's Liam Tancock is up in the men's individual medley and finishes fourth, behind Laszlo Cseh. That should be enough to go through.

1.06pm: Diego has scored for Brazil, giving them a 1-0 lead over China. I missed it, because I was checking in on some badminton, where Denmark and Poland are one game all in the men's doubles.

1.10pm: James Goddard is up in heat six of the medley, in which he is blessed just to splutter through the slipstream of the greatest individual that ever lived John Inverdale. I mean Michael Phelps. Phelps won it fairly confidently, but Ryan Lochte in heat five also looked formidable. Godard was fifth and qualified in 13th overall for the semis. Tancock goes through in 14th.

1.17pm Guardian Online Sport Editor Sean Ingle's latest article about women's gymnastics has kicked up some stink in the comments box. Are the competing girls Sindys or not Sindys? Stick your oar in by clicking the link above.

1.21pm: The French team breaks the women's 4x200m freestyle relay Olympic record in heat one in the Beijing pool. GB are up in heat two.

1.23pm: Pete Nichols in Beijing is rubbing his hands together over the prospect of Roger Federer and Rafael Nadal meeting at the Olympics.

1.33pm: Incompetent Britain alert! Great Britain's women finish sixth in their heat of the 200m freestyle relay, and spectacularly miss the final after finishing ninth overall. They pay the price for resting the top two swimmers over this distance, presumably for the final that they have now failed to reach. That really is some spectacularly bumbling incompetence from Britain and four red-faced women in swimming suits stare at Sharon Davies's microphone and say they're "gutted". No kidding. By their own admission, Jo Jackson, Hannah Miley, Fran Halsall and Melanie Marshall did all they could, but I'm really not sure team GB is strong enough to send out a B-team in any Olympic event.

1.38pm: The French teenager Alize Cornet has shown some youthful impudence to take the first set off Serena Williams in the tennis. She was 5-1 up, was pegged back to 5-3, but served out for the opening set. Meanwhile, some half-time football scores: China 0-1 Brazil; New Zealand 0-1 Belgium; Argentina 1-0 Serbia; Ivory Coast 0-0 Australia.

1.47pm The BBC coverage has suddenly become a bit mumsy as Sue Barker welcomes to the studio the British cycling medalists Emma Pooley and Nicole Cooke for some comfortable sofa-based chatter. Also present is Sharon Laws, who can't wear a medal proudly around her neck because she didn't win one. But "you work as a team" says Barker, attempting to include Laws, but then follows up with the zinger: "How did it feel to win your medal, Emma?"

1.50pm: This is what's wrong with British sport: Sue Barker has now just excitedly asked the British cyclists what it's like to be hanging around at the Olympic village and, conspiratorially, "Come on, who have you seen?" as though they are stupid little fan girls hanging round hoping for a glimpse of Michael Phelps.

1.55pm This is what the Olympics is all about, burly females lifting heavy weights in one swift motion. Yes, it's the women's snatch. (Joke (c) minute-by-minute coverage, London Olympics 1908.)

2pm: Some of your emails: "Re: 1252 entry: Manchester United's Dong? I thought Dion Dublin retired. HONK!" (Andrew Seaman); "After looking at the medal table I was curious to find that Russia is only
a teaspoonful ahead of the Team GB, so different from memories of the past. Then I did my sums with my 'Coldwar' head on and found that the USSR (if it still existed) would actually be in third place with 5 golds, 11 silvers and 16 bronzes, but still miles behind the new Big Two." (Phil Horton, and his coldwar head); "Does anyone know what happened in the following event: men in the most ludicrous hats I have ever seen cycled alone along public roads, accompanied only by one or two 4WD vehicles, and a British guy (Cummings?) was occasionally indicated to be no. 1, though the commentators said he could not sustain it (or something), but never explained what it was the cyclists were actually trying to achieve (i.e. to win), or what it was that Cummings(?) could or could not sustain - did he win? Or is it still going on, and am I actually for once watching a live, rather than recorded, event on my Philippines Olympic channel?" (Al Parkes).

See what we have to deal with?

2.05pm: Serena Williams is battling back into contention in the tennis, and is 4-1 up in the second set. Messrs Murray lost their first set 6-1.

2.10pm I've just picked up a feed of the Great Britain men's hockey match against Holland. I'm going to stick with this, only because I really can't trust myself with the women's weightlifting. And it seems I can't trust you lot either, if the smut arriving in my inbox is anything to go by. You know who you are, Alan Varrow.

2.15pm OK, so this hockey is delicately poised after Great Britain won their first match but lie behind the hot favourites Australia and today's opponents, Holland. GB have a penalty corner as we first arrive and although they win another attempt with the first effort, the second is squandered. Nil-nil it remains, with 19 minutes remaining in the first period.

2.17pm: Brazil go 3-0 up against China in the football, effectively knocking out the hosts (unless they can find four goals in the last 15 minutes). Thiago Neves got the third, drilling it past the despairing dive of the Chinese goalkeeper from 25 yards. He also got the second, although I didn't see it I'm afraid. Still 0-0 in the hockey.

2.23pm: I've never experienced the joy of listening to Olympic football on headphones while watching Olympic hockey on the screen. It means that a commentary of "Ronaldinho, Marcello, Ronaldinho..." accompanies pictures of (I must admit) unknown men carrying sticks. Another penalty corner for Great Britain, though.

2.24pm GB waste the penalty corner as news reaches that Andy and Jamie Murray have crashed out of the tennis in what can only be described as ignominy, 6-1, 6-3 to France's Arnaud Clement and Michael Llodra.

2.29pm: Robert van der Horst comes that near to opening the scoring in the hockey as he slices through the GB defence, then lifts the ball over the goalkeeper but onto the post. Still 0-0 but that was dreadful defending from England and a lovely mazy run from the Dutchman.

2.30pm: The Olympic hockey, by the way, has meant a return to the BBC commentary box for Barry Davies, who I never really liked during his self-important pomp, but now feel quite sorry for in a sentimental way because Motty got to carry on while he was sent out to pasture. I always preferred Motson back then, when there was something like a media-contrived Blur v Oasis battle between the two of them, but I think I might have been wrong. Davies is quite restrained here, although he's still doing that staccato-style commentary where he says one .... word ... every .... couple ... of ... seconds ... andthengarblesloadsoutallatoncesoyoucannotreallyfollowit.

2.35pm: Bouncing round the various wire services (other news providers are available), it seems that Venus Williams is through to the quarter finals of the tennis after beating Victoria Azarenka of Belarus; Argentina beat Serbia in the football; the German handball left back is out of the tournament with a knee injury but countryman Benjamin Kleibrink won a gold medal in the men's individual foil. It's 0-0 at half time in the hockey.

2.40pm: And more results: Football: Ivory Coast 1-0 Australia; New Zealand 0-1 Belgium; China 0-3 Brazil (China out). Meanwhile, the heavyweights are in the boxing ring, and the huge Zhanh Zhilei, of China, battered his Moroccan opponent in the first round.

2.49pm: A possible minor controversy brewing in the boxing ring, where the Moroccan boxer Amanissi has, as yet, refused to land a punch at Zhanh Zhilei through the first three rounds. Amanissi is 10-0 down and it's a complete mismatch, with the Moroccan passive enough, according to the commentators, that he could be disqualified for his negativity. There's nothing too sinister about it; he's just completely inept and probably shouldn't be there and is now getting booed from the crowd. And that's it, he loses 15-0 and becomes only the second boxer in more than 150 bouts at these Games to fail to trouble the scorers.

2.53pm: The hockey is back, and it's been a pretty impressive show from GB, who have held it to 0-0 against the Dutch, who were the runners up in Athens and much-fancied here. Meanwhile, the individual dressage competition is back underway, where there might be an outside medal chance for GB in the form of Jane Gregory.

2.59pm: Holland fail to convert a penalty corner -- that's three I've seen now, and no goals. I thought the conversion rate was slightly higher than that, but maybe not. A Dutchman has also just posted a pretty good score in the dressage, apparently, and in the absence of any personal knowledge, I'll believe anything I hear from a plummy-voiced lady representing the British Broadcasting Corporation.

3.01pm: Serena Williams has come from behind to beat Alize Cornet and book her place in the quarter-finals of the women's singles tennis. She lost the first set, but ended up winning 3-6, 6-3, 6-4.

3.10pm: You can lead a horse to the disco, but you can't make it dance. Or can you? I'll confess I know nothing about dressage, but that's pretty much what this is, right. Dancing horses. Still 0-0 in the hockey.

3.15pm: One of the hockey referees is called Grime. Which is kind of noteworthy, if you're trying to text commentate on a 0-0 draw in a game you don't know much about and when the only emails you're getting are correcting (admitedly quite major) typos from earlier posts. Meanwhile, the British player James Tindall has just been sent for a spell on the sidelines for hoiking his stick around an opponent's ankles while he was charging in on goal. That's a foul in any sport. With sticks.

3.18pm: And Tindall has been properly punished. His tackle gives the Dutch a penalty corner, which they whip into their dangerman Taeke Taekeme, who slaps it into the bottom corner. The keeper got a touch, but it was far too hard and accurate and Holland now lead 1-0 with about six minutes left.

3.21pm: Another penalty corner for the Dutch, this time the result of another crude trip by the British side. This time, though, Wilson in the British goal pulls off a terrific diving save. The dancing horses have a tendency to crash my computer when I try to watch them, so I might hold off for a while.

3.25pm: That's it, Holland have won the hockey and Barry Davies is back to his sanctimonious best. The goal was scored "from a penalty corner given away, quite frankly, needlessly" he says, and I bet you can just hear his distinctive tones running through that sentence. Great Britain are now third in the standings but have it all to do. They have to beat all the lower ranked countries, then overpower the reigning champions and tournament favourites Australia to progress. Let's face it, it ain't gonna happen.

3.30pm: Boxing now -- this is more fun than I could possibly imagine -- as David Price, the super super super heavyweight (6ft 8in, no less), from Liverpool, goes up against Russia's European champion Islam Timurziev. Timurziev is a massive favourite, but Price is simply massive and hops over the ropes in one bound. They're off

3.35pm: The first of four two-minute rounds goes to the Russian, 2-0. Price can count himself unlucky not to be only one behind after a decent body blow should definitely have scored, but the judges ruled otherwise. Timurziev's second point comes from the last punch of the round.

3.40pm: Wow! Massive upset in the boxing as two huge right-hands from David Price ends this one! The first puts the European champion down on one knee and earns him a standing count, then the Russian walks straight onto another one from the giant Liverpudlian and the referee stops it. Perhaps the decision to stop it was a bit premature, but Price is bounding across the ring and that's a great victory for the Brit. "Ee never gets knocked out, 'im," says Price at the end.

3.42pm: That's a terrific result for Price. Timurziev was the favourite for the gold medal, and definitely fancied to beat Price. But the 6ft 8in David slayed the 6ft 2in Goliath, or something, and that's that. Price is through.

And with that terrific one-two from Price, we're calling this off for the day. Good to finish this watch on a high note, especially after the last-gasp hockey capitulation and the calamitous women's 200m freestyle relay. Thanks for your emails and join us tomorrow at an ungodly hour for more action from Beijing. Goodnight/day/eveing/bye.
